awd_titl_txt: Greater than the sum of its parts? The role of mechanical sensitivity and integration in the evolution of power-amplified systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Trap-jaw ants are renowned for their extreme ability to amplify power with their mouthparts, which can generate forces hundreds of times greater than their body weight and reach speeds over 60 meters per second (over 130 miles per hour). Moreover, they do this using very simple, fracture resistant materials. The research will combine high-speed videography, biomechanics, and mathematics to characterize and model power-amplification in a diverse group of trap-jaw ants. The findings will provide insight into the mechanisms animals use to achieve extremely high speeds and forces with their limbs and to determine how variation in these high-performance biological systems generates diverse animal forms. The research also has the potential to inform biologically-inspired applications for robotics and machinery. The project will provide interdisciplinary research training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students, including those from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields. The researchers will also run robotics summer camps for children, exposing students to the many ways insects can be used to provide inspiration for innovations in technology and engineering.

The objective of this research is to examine the mechanical sensitivity and integration of power-amplified systems using a combination of experimental data and computer-based biomechanical models. The results of these mechanical analyses will be incorporated into phylogenetic comparative analyses to test whether patterns of mechanical sensitivity influence morphological and ecological diversification. Specifically, the research will take advantage of repeated transitions to power amplification in trap-jaw ants to explore how performance metrics (such as speed, force and energy) respond to shifts in morphology. The power-amplified trap-jaw system is composed of multiple components (i.e. muscle, latch, spring) all of which may be important to several aspects of performance (i.e. speed, force). The specific aims of the project are to 1) evaluate how various performance variables of the trap-jaw system (speed, force, damage resistance) vary with morphological changes in components of the system,  2) test multiple hypotheses for the source of the power-amplifying mechanism in trap-jaw ants, and 3) determine how patterns of biomechanical integration influence evolutionary patterns within and among trap-jaw clades. The interdisciplinary research approach offers a mechanistic framework for evaluating the integration and evolution of biomechanical systems, and how ecological function can influence morphological diversification. The research findings have the potential to provide translational applications for the bio-inspired design of high-performance robotic systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Trap-jaw ants are renowned for their ability to amplify force and speed with their mandibles, generating bite forces hundreds of times greater than their body weight and reaching snapping speeds over 60 m/s (~130 mph). To achieve such speed and power, they utilize a latch-mediated spring actuated system (LaMSA). This LaMSA system allows them to store energy in a biological ?spring?, a tendon or part of the exoskeleton. Releasing the energy all at once creates ultra-fast motions. Similar structures are found in the grasshopper legs, chameleon tongues, and the design of a variety of products (i.e. mousetraps). Trap-jaw mechanisms have evolved multiple times across ants, which is surprising considering how complex the system is, requiring multiple integrated structures (spring, latch, etc.). Tracing the evolution of such complex biological systems is complicated: how do these systems evolve piecemeal into fully integrated mechanisms. The objective of this project was to examine the mechanics of trap-jaw ants as a case study for understanding how these complex systems evolve.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

            The first aim of this project was to test how trap-jaw performance (speed, force, power) is influenced by components of the system. We created a muscle model estimating force production in ants by measuring muscle fiber orientation and number and then validated model estimates against experimental bite force data from live ants. We also collected spring data directly from several clades of trap-jaw ants using the Advanced Photon Light Source at National Argonne Laboratory. Using their giant particle accelerator along with an ultra-high-speed video camera, we observed the spring mechanism (head capsule) deforming during a strike. Combining this movement data with material data allows us to estimate spring mechanics in the system.

           These data were used to inform a comprehensive model for the entire trap-jaw system. The model is a variation on a LaMSA "toy" model, so called as it strips the system down to its basic components in order to better understand their function. We used this model to examine how components of the system (spring, muscle, latch , etc.) influence performance variables (speed, force, power, etc.). We found that trap-jaw ants have evolved a specific set of components that allow them to achieve high performance in speed, force and power simultaneously, something previously thought not possible in other LaMSA systems. This model also led to a new protocol for examining complex biomechanical systems with multiple performance outputs; holding great promise for examining such systems in other biological organisms.

            The final aim of this project was to use our understanding of the mechanism to analyze the evolution of the trap-jaw system across ants. The evolution of the trap-jaw system was mapped out across one of the largest Genera of ants: Strumigenys. This genus itself, comprised of over 800 species, has evolved the trap-jaw mechanism 7-10 independent times. We explored the variation in head and jaw shape across this clade to understand how such a complex system could seemingly evolve so easily. We found that there is little difference in how integrated the head and jaws are between trap-jaw and non-trap-jaw species, implying that it takes minimal structural change for the trap-jaw system to evolve, potentially explaining its proclivity. This study establishes a framework for synthesizing biomechanical data with evolutionary methods in order examine the evolution of complex biological systems.

BROADER IMPACT

            Outside the field of evolutionary biomechanics, this work establishes a framework for assessing a range of topics in bioinspired design, such as assessing how to manipulate components of a system to increase multiple performance variables. The framework also offers a specific roadmap for engineers interested in the creation of bioinspired systems based on LaMSA mechanisms in nature. The new data on trap-jaw systems gives insight into how rate-dependency in biological materials interacts with traumatic impacts and influences tissue damage on multiple scales; a major interest in biomedical fields dealing with the effects of trauma on sensitive tissues such as heart or brain.

             This work has also created opportunities for training K-12 students from underrepresented groups in STEM. We worked with a local public fabrication lab to organize a Robotics/Biomechanics workshop for local students associated with a neighborhood after-school center.  Students were exposed to design principles and learned to use digital fabrication tools. We learned a great deal from this experience and plan on implementing what we have learned in future summer camps. We also ran a half-day activity for a Multi-lingual Learners Camp run by the local school district. This was part of a larger, multi-week camp for grade school students for whom English is a second language. Reworking material from the robotics course involved creating components that encouraged the students to describe their projects both verbally and in writing, to practice their English. Future plans involve incorporating multilingual components into all of our outreach activities.
